Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: The regular weekly Shabbat service is approaching.
Story:
It was 2 a.m. when my phone buzzed, jolting me from restless sleep. I saw my friend’s name and answered immediately. Her voice was raw, trembling—her father had just passed away. She needed me, not as a rabbi, but as her friend. I listened, murmuring comfort, feeling her pain as if it were my own. I wanted to stay on the line all night, to be the friend she deserved, to hold her together as she unraveled.

But as the minutes ticked by, my mind drifted to the sermon I hadn’t finished. Shabbat was only hours away, and my congregation would gather, expecting words of hope and guidance. They relied on me to be prepared, to lead them with wisdom and strength. I felt the weight of their expectations pressing down, even as my friend’s sobs echoed in my ear.

Torn between the urgent need of my friend and the sacred duty to my community, I sat in the darkness, heart pounding, wrestling with the impossible choice before me.
